founding_conditions.starting_capital: $500K-$1M, can raise more if opportunity merits
founding_conditions.founder_1: operator, Argentina citizen, US resident, English+Spanish
founding_conditions.founder_2: ML/AI Masters Georgia Tech, US citizen
founding_conditions.operating_geo: US primary, operate FROM US with international intelligence. Not relocating — using comparative data to confirm/challenge US-centric analytical biases.
founding_conditions.credentials: no CPA/JD/MD — willing to acquire licensed businesses
founding_conditions.languages: English+Spanish native, others = cost adder not blocker
founding_conditions.optimization_target: opportunity quality + VC differentiation, NOT capital fit

history.reason: Post Cycle 3: themes established, need depth over novelty. Boost data specificity for unit economics verification. Boost cross-signal reinforcement to detect convergences.
Post Cycle 6 counter-signal revolution: added counter_signal_severity (1.5) and competitive_density (1.3) as permanent grading dimensions.

Post Cycle 8: added market_price_confirmation (1.1) as grading dimension. When equity markets (staffing stocks, sector ETFs) confirm or contradict a thesis, this should modestly adjust scores. Weight is conservative (1.1) because market signals can be noisy — the staffing canary is unusually clean and direct.

running_patterns.description: P2+P5 Divergence Corridor: Professional services in liquidation cascade while healthcare faces permanent labor shortage
running_patterns.cycle_8_note: MARKET CONFIRMATION via staffing stock collapse. Robert Half -51% (most professional-focused) vs Kelly Services -20% (mixed with industrial) shows the divergence is specifically in professional labor. Healthcare ETF +20% confirms the other side. Pattern is now confirmed by both government data AND equity markets.

running_patterns.description: P2+P3 Credit-Squeeze Accelerator: Falling credit availability preventing incumbent restructuring while AI entrants need minimal capital
running_patterns.status: confirmed — transitioning from squeeze to deployment
running_patterns.cycle_8_note: Capital Environment Index hits 100.0 (maximum). The squeeze phase that blocked incumbent restructuring in 2024-2025 is ending. Capital is now available and cheap. This TRANSITIONS the pattern: the damage from the squeeze is permanent (firms that needed capital didn't get it), but new capital is now flowing. For AI-native entrants, this is doubly favorable — incumbents weakened by the squeeze, new capital available for building.

running_patterns.description: P1+P3 Cost Floor Unlock: 1000x inference cost collapse enabling new tier of agentic businesses
running_patterns.cycle_8_note: P3 Cost Collapse Index hits 100.0 (MAXIMUM). This is the peak of the cost floor unlock — the gap between human labor cost and AI capability cost has never been wider. The index measures productivity growth, ULC decline, corporate profit growth, and AI inference cost trajectory, and ALL components are at their most favorable readings. The risk at maximum: if everyone sees this, competitive density increases everywhere (reinforcing P-006).

running_patterns.description: P7 Timing Arbitrage: Companies cutting human capacity before AI can deliver, creating service vacuums
running_patterns.cycle_8_note: STRONGEST CYCLE YET for P7. Staffing canary collapse provides MARKET-PRICED confirmation that professional labor is being cut at structural (not cyclical) rates. Beveridge Curve r=-0.658 confirms the mismatch is structural. But Klarna's reversal proves the cuts are premature — AI-only doesn't work for complex/emotional tasks. The vacuum between 'companies cutting humans' and 'AI can't replace them yet' is widening, which is exactly the Customer Support Vacuum thesis. This pattern drove the largest single-cycle score increase in any opportunity (+7 for Customer Support).

running_patterns.description: PE Roll-Up Vulnerability: PE firms deploying $200B+ into fragmented sector roll-ups may face Minsky distress as AI disruption outpaces their restructuring capacity
running_patterns.cycle_8_note: Staffing canary collapse is a potential early warning for PE roll-up stress. PE roll-ups in professional services (accounting, consulting, etc.) are buying human labor capacity. If that labor is depreciating at the rate staffing stocks suggest (-51% for professional staffing), PE models may be overpaying. No direct distress signal yet from Crete/Ascend/Accrual, but the staffing canary may be a 6-12 month leading indicator. Upgraded from 'moderate' to 'moderate-strong'.

running_patterns.description: Competitive Density as Universal Gate: Every sector flagged by the Principles Engine has already attracted $1B+ in VC/PE. The framework's strength is also its weakness — obvious disruption is obvious to everyone.
running_patterns.status: confirmed — reinforced by staffing opportunity rejection
running_patterns.cycle_8_note: Staffing industry disruption was assessed as a potential opportunity and REJECTED because competitive density exceeds $5B+ (Indeed, LinkedIn, Upwork, Deel, Remote.com) AND the category is shrinking. This adds another data point to the Universal Gate thesis: even when we identify a collapsing industry (staffing stocks -51%), the entry point is still blocked by density. The distinction between 'the disruption is real' and 'there's an entry point for us' remains the engine's most important analytical contribution.

running_patterns.description: Staffing Canary as Macro Leading Indicator: Staffing company equity prices collapse 6-12 months before government employment data confirms structural labor shifts. The gradient (RHI -51% vs KELYA -20%) reveals professional-specific disruption.
running_patterns.status: NEW — first observation, needs quarterly tracking
running_patterns.cycle_8_note: FIRST OBSERVATION. The staffing canary is the engine's most reliable external validation signal because: (1) it's market-priced (billions in aggregate trading volume, hard to manipulate), (2) it has a clear causal mechanism (if companies need fewer temps/contractors, staffing firms lose revenue before government counts the unemployed), and (3) the gradient between professional-focused (RHI) and mixed (KELYA) firms reveals the specificity of the disruption. Must track quarterly to validate the 6-12 month leading indicator hypothesis.

running_patterns.description: Composite Index Convergence at Maximum: P3 Cost Collapse and Capital Environment both at 100.0 simultaneously, creating the most favorable macro setup for AI-native business formation — but also potentially flooding all sectors with competitive capital.
running_patterns.status: NEW — first observation, monitoring for density amplification
running_patterns.cycle_8_note: FIRST OBSERVATION. The convergence at maximum has a dual interpretation: (1) FAVORABLE — AI costs at minimum, capital at maximum, structural mismatch confirmed. Best time to build. (2) DANGEROUS — if everyone sees this, capital floods into every AI-adjacent sector, making competitive density worse everywhere. The tension between P-008 (favorable macro) and P-006 (density gate) is the engine's central strategic question. The resolution: find sectors where domain-specific insight (not generic pattern recognition) creates the entry. Veterinary services and managed hybrid customer support are the current best candidates.

methodology_tracking.key_finding_cycle_9: Engine had only ONE discovery method (LLM brainstorming) which exhausted after Cycle 3. Adding bottom-up screener immediately produced 3 new pipeline candidates. Thompson Sampling allocation will ensure future cycles systematically try untested methods (IO tables, shift-share, geographic arbitrage deep-dive).
methodology_tracking.exploration_budget: 20% of cycle capacity reserved for methods with < 3 applications
untested_methods_needing_trials: io_table_propagation (0 applications, built but never used)
shift_share_decomposition (0 applications, built but never used)

agent_a.notes: Cycle 8 expanded Agent A's scope to include equity market signals (staffing stocks), composite indices (P3, Capital Environment, Beveridge Curve), international comparative data (UAE, Germany, World Bank), and sector ETF divergence. These four new data categories represent a qualitative expansion of the engine's sensing capability — moving from government statistics and company filings to market-priced signals and international comparisons.

common_kill_reasons: Regulatory prohibition of core value proposition
Incumbent moat + proven startup failure pattern
Category shrinking (staffing — no entry point even with disruption thesis)
agent_b.notes: Cycle 8 Agent B performed re-verification of all 3 active opportunities with new data (staffing canary, composite indices, sector ETFs, international data). All 3 scored upward: Customer Support +7, LATAM Nearshoring +5, Veterinary Services +3. Also assessed staffing industry disruption as a potential NEW opportunity and REJECTED it — the first 'signal-only, not-opportunity' determination. The engine's effective filtering remains aggressive: 72% kill+park rate across all 14 verifications, with an additional rejected-as-opportunity. Only 3 of 14 remain in active scanning.

key_unknowns: CRITICAL: Is the customer support SERVICE layer (managed hybrid human+AI) sparse or crowded? This is the make-or-break question for the co-#1 opportunity. The TOOL layer (Intercom, Zendesk) is crowded, but is the SERVICE layer (we operate your support team with our hybrid model) also crowded? If sparse, this becomes a PURSUE. If crowded, it may need to PARK like everything else.

CRITICAL: What are Mars/IDEXX's specific plans for veterinary practice-level AI? Mars has a $20B pet care division and could enter practice operations AI at any time. IDEXX dominates diagnostics — do they have practice management ambitions? This has been pending since Cycle 7 and must be answered in Cycle 9.

What are the actual acquisition economics for independent vet practices? What does a typical practice cost? What are EBITDA multiples? Can 2 founders acquire and operate a single practice as proof of concept?

How crowded is AI-augmented professional services nearshoring? Distinguish from traditional BPO (Globant, Accenture), from AI-only automation, and from generic nearshoring. The specific niche is 'AI tools deployed to LATAM professionals serving US clients at premium-over-BPO pricing.'
Will BLS/JOLTS data confirm the staffing canary signal within 6-12 months? If so, the staffing canary becomes a validated predictive instrument. If not, the equity market may have overreacted.
Does P3 at maximum create a competitive density feedback loop? If capital is cheap and AI is cheap, does every sector get more crowded, making it even harder to find sparse entry points?

Can the international data (UAE, Germany, World Bank 16 countries) be used to identify opportunities that are US-specific vs. global? The LATAM thesis benefits from US-specificity — what other opportunities might?
Are PE roll-ups (Crete, Ascend, Accrual) showing any early stress now that the staffing canary suggests labor depreciation is accelerating?
What is the optimal cycle scheduling? Cycle 8 added 4 new data categories — should some be collected more frequently (equity markets = weekly?) while others remain quarterly?
next_cycle_suggestions: PRIORITY 1 — MAKE OR BREAK: Competitive density deep-dive on customer support SERVICE layer (managed hybrid human+AI). Search for: companies offering managed hybrid support (not just tools), their funding levels, their scale. Key question: is this sparse (like vet) or crowded (like everything else)? If sparse, Customer Support Vacuum Filler advances to PURSUE. If crowded, it may park.

PRIORITY 2 — OVERDUE: Deep-verify veterinary services. Mars/IDEXX threat assessment (what are their specific AI/practice management plans?). State licensing map (which states allow non-vet ownership of practices?). Practice acquisition economics (EBITDA multiples, typical acquisition cost, working capital needs). Unit economics modeling (revenue per vet, cost per vet with AI augmentation, margin improvement projection).

PRIORITY 3: AI-augmented nearshoring competitive scan. Who is specifically doing 'LATAM professionals + AI tools serving US professional services clients'? Not traditional BPO, not AI-only, not generic nearshoring. What professional services vertical (accounting? legal research? customer success?) shows highest arbitrage and sparsest competition?

PRIORITY 4: Deeper international data analysis. Process the UAE, Germany, and World Bank 16-country datasets collected in Cycle 8. Use for: (a) confirming US-specificity of structural labor shift, (b) identifying countries where Baumol stored energy is highest (largest gap between human labor cost and AI capability), (c) benchmarking staffing canary against international staffing firms (Adecco, Randstad).

PRIORITY 5: Staffing canary propagation tracking. Monitor RHI, MAN, KELYA quarterly. Compare to BLS/JOLTS releases. Track whether the 6-12 month leading indicator hypothesis validates. Also monitor international staffing firms (Adecco, Randstad) for global vs. US-specific signal.

PRIORITY 6: P3 maximum density feedback analysis. With P3 and capital environment both at 100.0, is competitive density increasing across sectors we've already scanned? Re-scan veterinary services density to ensure it hasn't degraded since Cycle 7.
MONITOR: PE roll-up health — Crete, Ascend, Accrual. Check earnings, debt covenants, client retention. Staffing canary may be early warning.
MONITOR: DOGE federal workforce — track service delivery degradation. If measurable, federal services vacuum becomes more actionable.
PROCESS: Add market_price_confirmation (1.1 weight) to grading framework — implemented in Cycle 8.

PROCESS: Consider adding equity market screening as a FIRST-PASS filter before even scanning sectors. If a sector's staffing/service companies are collapsing in equity markets, the disruption is real and priced — then check density.

kill_patterns.opportunity_killed: Healthcare Staffing Gap — AI-Augmented Nurse Capacity Multiplier
kill_patterns.kill_reason: Nurse ratio manipulation is illegal. Federal bills H.R. 3415 and S. 1709 explicitly prohibit counting technology as a substitute for nurse staffing in ratio calculations. California SB 596 increases penalties for ratio violations. The core value proposition — shifting nurse-patient ratios from 1:4 to 1:12 through AI monitoring — is not merely difficult, it is prohibited by law. Additionally, NNU (largest US nurses' union) is running a funded national anti-AI campaign across 12 states, creating organized political opposition to any technology-as-substitute framing.
kill_patterns.constraint_violated: regulatory — federal and state law explicitly blocks core value proposition
kill_patterns.theoretical_basis: Baumol cost disease confirmed in healthcare but regulation preserves it. Schumpeter destruction blocked by legal protection of incumbent model. Jevons demand expansion blocked by ratio mandates. Minsky analysis shows WE would be the speculative actor, not the incumbents.

precedent_failures.outcome: Shut down. Healthcare AI integration exponentially harder than projected. 18-36 month enterprise sales cycles consumed capital.
precedent_failures.relevance: Direct precedent at 1000x our capital level

competing_incumbents.name: Epic Systems
competing_incumbents.threat: Building competing AI monitoring and staffing optimization from incumbent data/integration position

additional_kill_factors: 80-99% false alarm rate in clinical monitoring (alarm fatigue documented)
Enterprise sales cycles 18-36 months in healthcare
kill_patterns.invalidation_condition: Kill becomes invalid ONLY if: (1) H.R. 3415 / S. 1709 both die in committee AND no replacement legislation introduced, AND (2) NNU reverses its anti-AI campaign or loses political influence, AND (3) at least one state explicitly allows AI as substitute in ratio calculations. All three conditions must be met. Monitor quarterly.
kill_patterns.preserved_insight: The demographic signal is VALID — healthcare adding 709K jobs/yr with permanent shortage. The PROBLEM is real. Only this specific SOLUTION (ratio manipulation via AI) is killed. Adjacent opportunities in healthcare that help compliance rather than circumvent it remain viable for scanning.

kill_patterns.kill_reason: Incumbent moat (Intuit/QuickBooks 80%+ market share with $100M OpenAI partnership) plus proven startup failure pattern. Bench.co raised $113M, built exactly this product, reached 35K customers, then catastrophically failed Dec 2024 — unit economics never worked at SMB price points. Pilot raised $325M from Sequoia/Bezos and achieved only 0.4% market penetration. The market has been tested at $113M and $325M by elite teams and has been proven non-viable as a standalone product. Additionally, 70% of SMBs still use paper-based bookkeeping after 43 years of digital alternatives — the adoption barrier is behavioral, not economic.
kill_patterns.constraint_violated: market — incumbent moat + proven startup failure pattern + behavioral adoption resistance
kill_patterns.theoretical_basis: Jevons demand expansion blocked by behavioral inelasticity (70% on paper after 43 years). Coase correctly predicts outsourcing value but Intuit already captured it. Schumpeter analysis shows Intuit IS the creative destroyer, not the victim. No Minsky vulnerability — Intuit's model strengthens with AI.

precedent_failures.outcome: Catastrophic failure Dec 2024. 35K customers stranded mid-tax-season. Unit economics never worked at SMB price points.
precedent_failures.relevance: Exact same product thesis at 200x our capital

precedent_failures.outcome: 0.4% market penetration despite elite backing and massive capital.
precedent_failures.relevance: Proves even $325M cannot dislodge SMB accounting incumbent

competing_incumbents.name: Intuit (QuickBooks)
competing_incumbents.threat: $100M OpenAI partnership, actively building agentic AI agents within QuickBooks. Has distribution, data, and habit moat.

additional_kill_factors: 70% of SMBs still on paper after 43 years of digital alternatives
CAC for SMBs structurally too high relative to LTV
Quality control at scale requires more humans than projected (Bench lesson)
kill_patterns.invalidation_condition: Kill becomes invalid ONLY if: (1) Intuit loses significant market share (below 60%) due to product failure or regulatory action, OR (2) a new distribution channel emerges that bypasses Intuit's platform lock-in, OR (3) a vertical-specific niche is identified where QuickBooks does not serve well (cannabis, crypto, international trade). Condition 3 would not invalidate the general kill but could create a niche exception.
kill_patterns.preserved_insight: The distressed SMB signal is VALID — 24K bankruptcies, overhead costs at $50-100K for 5-20 person firms. The PROBLEM is real. But the SOLUTION cannot be a horizontal back-office product competing with Intuit.

kill_patterns.kill_reason: Extreme competitive density. Total VC/PE deployed exceeds $2-4B+. DeepL (~$100M+ raised, ~$2B valuation), Unbabel ($91M), Lilt ($92.5M), Phrase/Memsource ($150M+ PE-backed), Smartling ($60M), Lokalise ($50M+), Language I/O ($12M), and many others. Plus horizontal AI competitors (Google Translate, Microsoft Translator, Meta NLLB, ChatGPT) competing at free or near-free tier. The translation market is simultaneously crowded by specialized startups AND commoditized by Big Tech free offerings. No viable entry point at $500K-$1M.
kill_patterns.constraint_violated: competitive_density — $2-4B+ deployed + Big Tech free-tier competition
kill_patterns.theoretical_basis: Schumpeter creative destruction IS happening in translation — but the creative destroyers are DeepL, Google, and Microsoft, not a new entrant. Jevons demand expansion (more content = more translation need) is real but captured by existing players. Coase transaction cost reduction benefits platforms with existing distribution.

competing_incumbents.name: DeepL
competing_incumbents.threat: ~$2B valuation, dominant in European enterprise translation, expanding globally

competing_incumbents.name: Google Translate
competing_incumbents.threat: Free for consumer use, integrated into Chrome/Android ecosystem, sets price floor at zero

additional_kill_factors: Big Tech offers free-tier that sets price floor at zero for consumer translation
Enterprise localization market fragmented among dozens of funded startups
EU AI Act may add transparency/compliance costs for translation AI
kill_patterns.invalidation_condition: Kill becomes invalid ONLY if: (1) a specific language pair or domain niche is identified with zero competition (unlikely), OR (2) a regulatory change creates a new translation requirement that existing players cannot serve. This is a permanent density kill — the sector will remain crowded.
kill_patterns.preserved_insight: Translation IS being disrupted by AI — the thesis is correct. But the disruption is being executed by well-funded incumbents and Big Tech. No room for a $500K entrant.

kill_patterns.kill_reason: Extreme competitive density plus the most expensive precedent failure in our scanning universe. Convoy raised $900M and shut down in October 2023, with assets acquired by Flexport. Total VC/PE deployed in digital freight exceeds $5-8B+: Transfix ($275M), Loadsmart ($200M+), Emerge ($220M), project44 ($500M+), FourKites ($250M), and others. C.H. Robinson ($24B gross revenue) is investing heavily in Navisphere AI from dominant incumbent position. The digital brokerage model has been tested at massive capital levels and has NOT displaced traditional brokers.
kill_patterns.theoretical_basis: Coase transaction cost reduction thesis is correct — freight brokerage is a coordination-cost business. But Convoy proved that reducing transaction costs via technology is not sufficient when incumbents have relationship moats, carrier networks, and balance sheet advantages. Schumpeter gap analysis: the gap was filled by traditional brokers adapting, not by digital disruptors replacing them.

precedent_failures.outcome: Shut down October 2023. Assets acquired by Flexport. Digital brokerage model could not achieve unit economics at scale despite nearly $1B in capital.
precedent_failures.relevance: 1800x our capital level. The most expensive validation that this thesis does not work.

competing_incumbents.name: C.H. Robinson
competing_incumbents.market_share: Largest freight broker globally (~$24B gross revenue)
competing_incumbents.threat: Investing heavily in Navisphere AI. Has carrier relationships, balance sheet for credit, and 100+ year operating history.

additional_kill_factors: FMCSA broker authority + $75K surety bond requirement
Freight market is highly cyclical — 2023-2024 recession devastated digital brokers
Carrier relationships (not technology) are the primary competitive moat
kill_patterns.invalidation_condition: Kill becomes invalid ONLY if: (1) autonomous trucking reaches scale (removes the carrier relationship dependency), OR (2) a specific freight niche (e.g., last-mile, cold chain, oversized loads) shows sparse competition. The general freight brokerage kill is permanent.
kill_patterns.preserved_insight: Freight brokerage IS a coordination-cost business ripe for technology disruption — the thesis is correct. But $900M proved the execution is exponentially harder than the thesis suggests. The incumbent moat is relationships, not technology.

top_kill_reasons.reason: Regulatory prohibition of core value proposition
Incumbent moat + proven startup failure pattern

stats.kill_index_observations: Cycle 7 adds competitive density as a kill category. K-003 and K-004 are the first 'pure density' kills — no regulatory barrier or incumbent moat, just too much capital already deployed. Combined with Cycle 6's kills, the pattern is clear: the Principles Engine correctly identifies macro disruption forces, but every sector it flags has already attracted $1B+ in capital. The search must move toward sectors requiring domain-specific insight that generic disruption frameworks miss. Veterinary services is the first candidate that passed all filters.
